video.title: The Best, Worst and Blandest of 2025 | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text: For the month of December, get 25% off
your first month or your first year of a
membership to the Second Win Patreon.
Supporting Independent Games Media means
you get more biting games criticism like
this
[music]
[music]
man. Great big airway obstructing
bollocks to the game awards. Claire
obscure game of the year. Fair enough.
But best indie and best debut indie. A.
It was made by ex Ubisoft lads. So if
that counts as a newcomer, so does
putting on a false mustache and running
to the back of the line for another free
sample at the Whole Foods. And B, a game
made by one dude in a shed out of
leftover pixels and crisp packets. That
is an indie game. A game that
commissioned all its character avatars
from someone on Deviant Art who earns
the bulk of their lipping drawing
snaggle puss fisting Winnie the Pooh.
That is an indie game. The game awards
badly need to acknowledge the middle
ground between that and AAA. I know. I
grew up in the Midlands, and I&#39;m sick of
explaining to people from London that
there&#39;s actually a lot of England you
have to get through before you&#39;re up
north. We don&#39;t all eat black puddings
or act in high fantasy HBO dramas. It&#39;s
gling cuz this was such a great year for
indies. I could have filled a top 10
easy. Not that AAA didn&#39;t make
significant contributions. And
incidentally, I could have probably done
a top 10 bland list as well. Rest
assured by 2025 best, worst, and
blandest awards is a complete Clare
Obscure free zone. That&#39;ll pay those
[ __ ] back for 1066.
fifth best. [sighs]
A brief word on what didn&#39;t make the
cut. Citizen Sleeper 2, good game.
Dispatch, good game. Nice tits, but I
reluctantly nudged them out of the top
five because it&#39;s mainly narrative that
makes those games. And it&#39;s still the
intersection between narrative and
gameplay that I find the most
interesting. DND dice rolls and dialogue
trees with all the impact of a sapling
on a train track don&#39;t cut it.
Therefore, my fifth best is Promise
Mascot Agency. Not quite as good
writing, but it let me ramp a tiny
Japanese truck off a cliff while firing
a squealing pink blob out for cannon at
a billboard I disagree with, and that
counts for a lot. Fifth Plantist.
[sighs]
I&#39;ve noticed that it&#39;s not uncommon for
the very last game I review in a year to
end up somewhere in my lists, which is
probably down to it still being fresh in
memory. So, bearing in mind that it&#39;s
about as fully recallable as any game
could possibly be at this point, I will
now list the parts of Metroid Prime 4
that I found interesting. Uh
oh. Samus does the Akira slide on her
motorbike at one point. Boy, Akira is a
good film, isn&#39;t it? I wish I&#39;d spent a
certain portion of this month watching
that fifth worst. [sighs]
I felt slightly bad about kicking more
[ __ ] out of Tales of the [ __ ] a The
Lord of the Rings pile of [ __ ] because
it was a lot more wholesome than most of
what I deal with, but then I realized,
wait a second, that&#39;s how they get you.
This is kin to the innocent batting of
the eyes my kids put on before admitting
where precisely they have been putting
peanut butter that does not
conventionally have any business with
peanut butter. Cozy does not mean
loweffort, and Tales of the Shire is
just that, a loweffort, cynical IP
exploiting exercise whose title needed
to pick a [ __ ] article and stick with
it. Fourth best, [sighs and gasps]
I&#39;m giving it to the Rogue Prince of
Persia because considered, apart from
the attached IP, it&#39;s a rather lovely
conjunction of tight combat and
traversal gameplay loops with some fun
story elements that pay off the rogike
format, and I only wish it had had a
little more depth in the late game.
Meanwhile, considered as not a part from
the attached IP, it&#39;s just rather
pleasing to see another nice thing come
from a long tortured name. quite
inspiring actually, like when someone
makes a beautiful piece of art out of a
big pile of discarded garbage. Fourth
plantest. [sighs]
It&#39;s a shame that after Doom 2016
reinvented the franchise with its
non-nonsense approach to demonic anatomy
lessons, the sequels seem to have gone,
&quot;But on the other hand, how about yes,
nonsense?&quot; And so Doom: The Dark Ages
brought us more of the same combat, but
constantly interrupted with incipid
vehicle sections and cutscenes from a
story that reads like an extremely
socially unaware person at a party,
excitedly telling you about their
Warhammer campaign, as they fail to
interpret the meaning of your persistent
attempts to move past them to the
bathroom door. Fourth worst. You might
say it&#39;s a little unfair to stick Split
Fiction in the worst list. The gameplay
and visuals are good and the work of no
doubt many talented individuals that it
would be cruel of me to tar just because
every word that comes out of the
protagonist&#39;s mouths makes me want to
shove them eyeball first onto both ends
of a railroad spike and push them into a
giant vat of printed out negative good
readads reviews. The writing is so
painful it eclipses any of the games
good qualities for me and trying to
focus on them can&#39;t help but bring to
mind the classic phrase. But apart from
that, Mrs. Lincoln, how was the play? At
best, [sighs]
there&#39;s nothing quite like a good
newspaper puzzle page to act as the
first bullwalk against my inevitable
future dementia. And I&#39;ve never played a
game that embodied the spirit of the
newspaper puzzle page better than Blue
Prince, the first person
explorationbased rogike puzzler that is
somehow simultaneously the logic puzzle,
the sudoku, and the cryptic crossword.
And it all spirals together to craft
this wonderfully immersive world that
comes to life before your eyes as you
place doorways and select blueprints for
Oh [ __ ] I just got that. Third
Blandest. You might expect that the game
that literally put me to sleep would
rank higher in the Bland five, but as
I&#39;ve said before, Third Blandist is the
true prize in the mediocrity stakes. And
for all that little nightmares is a
tedious slog through old ideas with an
obnoxious unwanted co-op focus that you
can observe aging in real time with its
frequent unreasonable deaths sucking all
tension out of what atmosphere it
manages to create. It does have the
saving grace of not being very long and
at least I came out of it thoroughly
well-rested.
Third worst. [sighs]
If Rogue Pop is a beautiful piece of art
coming out of a big pile of garbage, the
long-awaited Vampire the Masquerade
Bloodlines 2 demonstrates that process
running in precisely the opposite
direction. Bloodlines one was a game
that had plenty of flaws but had a
definite spark. One that raised the
question, could this be a seed that with
nurturing could sprout into something
truly great? Then many years later,
Bloodlines 2 came along and said, bug it
if we know. Want to do some shitty
combat? Not really. Well, how about
flinging yourself off a tall building?
Ooh, you read my mind. Bloodlines 2.
Second best. [sighs]
There&#39;s three rogue likes in my top five
this year, but you shouldn&#39;t read too
much into that. I always think rogike is
more of a medium than a genre at this
point. But looking at rogue pop and
blueprints, it&#39;s particularly the ways
rogue likes have explored storytelling
lately that have been giving them the
boost. and Hades has always shown how
that&#39;s done. Yes, I called Hades 2 a bit
of a the same but more of its sequel,
but I can&#39;t deny how much of my spare
time I&#39;ve spent on it this year. I&#39;ve
even been replaying Hades 1 because of
it, and I&#39;m sincerely missing the
ability to take baths with people in
both the game and reality. Actually,
second blandest. A day may yet come when
my bland five list does not feature a
Ubisoft open world game. And should it
come, I will not celebrate because that
would mean the industry somehow managed
to cough up five games that were blander
than a Ubisoft open world. Perhaps we
should thank Ubisoft for continuing to
gatekeep mediocrity. Assassin&#39;s Creed
Shadows being yet another overproduced,
overlar, busy work game with a plot
focused group to Oblivion fit only to be
ground up and recycled as packing
material for other better games. Then
again, perhaps not, because it&#39;s a big
pile of monkey spunk. Second worst. For
a scary moment there, I thought
condemning the Call of Duty franchise
was getting old, that there was nothing
more to be said. But I got to hand it to
them. Black Ops 7 exceeded all my
expectations for discovering new depths
of terribleness with a campaign equal
parts dull and bathroom carpet chewingly
insane that seemed to be actively
hostile to its audience. The only
positive I have is that at least Call of
Duty seems to be less racist these days.
Now it&#39;s just completely soulless. Maybe
they needed the racism to fire the
creative spark like with Kurt Cabain and
Heroine.
Best game. Yeah, I know. slight
hypocrisy to talk [ __ ] about the game
awards pushing a double A game like
Clare Obscure over genuine indie games
and then turn around and put another
double A game, The Altters, in my top
spot. But I&#39;d argue The Altars embodies
the spirit of The Underdog in that you
play as an underdog and five clones of
said underdog. Yes, the AI controversy
was a hiccup, but I don&#39;t want to let
that overshadow what I found to be a
singularly well-designed game on its
narrative level, gameplay level, and
every level in between. Plus, the main
actor had to put on like nine different
silly voices. And as someone who records
audio books, I wanted to express silly
voice solidarity.
Landist game. Oh boy, I&#39;ve been dreading
having to write this one up. It&#39;s
Borderlands 4. Okay, another grindathon
in the sense of both the core gameplay
loop and what the dialogue causes me to
do to my teeth. From the House of
Pitchford, a game so mind-numbingly one
note and poorly optimized that I
struggle even to think of interesting
ways to complain about it. Um, have you
noticed that it&#39;s very nearly an anagram
of bored slander, which is precisely
what I&#39;m currently doing to it?
An uncontroversial choice, but come on.
I don&#39;t see how anyone could possibly
argue that anything is worse than mind&#39;s
eye without venturing into comparisons
to chemical weapon usage against
civilian targets. In case it needs
restating, it&#39;s a dull shootout across
an utterly lifeless open world threaded
by a story demonstrating schizophrenia
beyond the reach of
psychopharmarmacology. And it really
illustrates that the people controlling
where all the money goes in the highle
games industry don&#39;t have the first clue
what they&#39;re [ __ ] doing. And perhaps
better results could be gleaned from
replacing them with literally anyone
else. or perhaps a room full of gently
sedated psums.
[music] Well, another year gone. And
before you think about skipping over
this list of Patreon names, let&#39;s not
lose sight of the fact that these
wonderful people are the reason Second
Win continues to exist. And if you want
our content to continue and would like
to see your name on this hall of heroes
and gain access to all kinds of secret
bonus videos as well, toddle along to
patreon.com/secwindgroup
and sign up to give us as little as a
dollar a month to keep us going. Anyway,
see you in the new year. Stick around
for the honorable mentions. You might
want to have a finger ready on the pause
button.
